moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. Nc3 Nf: I take time out to prevent anything on g5.
moves.8. fxe3 Ne7: I prepare a devastating central advance.
moves.9. a3: ? This doesn't help anything. Nothing was going to b4.
moves.10. Nxe5: ? This gave me a vital tempo.
moves.18. Rxf6 Qxf6: I am deviated from my attack. (His knight is still doomed by the way!)
moves.20. Qf1: ? Bd5 getting an escape square for the knight.
moves.20... Qc6: The knight is trapped. (This is a mistake. Qd6 or Qb6 were far better.)
moves.21... Qxc5 22. Bxa8 Qxc2 23. Qc1 Qxd3: An even exchange instead of a winning a piece.
moves.27... Nf4 28. Re1 e2 29. Ne5: Here I find a killer move.
moves.38. Nxg2: It would have been better to take the bishop.
moves.38... Bxg2 39. b4 Kf8 40. Kd4 Ke8 41. Kc: I start pushing my pawns since each king isn't budging.
moves.45. b5 h4 46. Ke5: He sees the need for help on the king side.
moves.49... axb6 50. axb6 Ba6: I stop the pawn. See why it is better to have bishop in a endgame like this!
moves.51. Kxg3 Ke7 52. Kf4 Kf6 53. Ke4 Ke6: ? Kg5! His king can't do any damage as I thought.
moves.57... Kc8 58. Kc6 Kb8 59. Kd7: ? Kd6 might have been a draw.
